page.title: 1.5.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will analyze points on and off a graph and interpret them in context. In explaining correspondences between equations, verbal descriptions, and graphs, you will hone your skill at making sense of problems.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use graphing technology to graph linear equations and identify solutions to the equations.
  • Explain how the coordinates of the points on the graph of a linear equation are related to the equation.
  • Explain the meaning of points on a graph in terms of the situation it represents when given the graph of a linear equation. 

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 1.5.1: Analyzing Graphs of Linear Equations 
  • 1.5.2: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 1
  • 1.5.2: Self Check
  • 1.5.3: Writing, Graphing, and Solving a Linear Equation
  • 1.5.3: Self Check
  • 1.5.4: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 2

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 1.5.5: Practice
  • 1.5.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 1.5.1: Analyzing Graphs of Linear Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Which one doesn’t belong?

A

B

C

D


Write your answer here:

Compare your answer to these sample responses:

  • A is the only graph that intersects the vertical axis at 0 (or that starts at the origin).
  • B is the only graph where the horizontal axis represents dollars and the vertical axis represents hours.
  • C is the only graph that is discrete, showing plotted points (that lie along a line) instead of a continuous line.
  • D is the only graph with a negative slope (or that slants downward from left to right).

page.title: 1.5.2: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 1
page.contents:
Activity

To get snacks for a class trip, Clare went to the “bulk” section of the grocery store, where she could buy any quantity of a product and the prices are usually good.

Clare purchased some salted almonds at $6 a pound and some dried figs at $9 per pound. She spent $75 before tax.


1. If she bought 2 pounds of almonds, how many pounds of figs did she buy?

Check your answer:
7 pounds


2. If she bought 1 pound of figs, how many pounds of almonds did she buy?

Check your answer:
11 pounds


3. Write an equation that describes the relationship between pounds of figs and pounds of almonds that Clare bought and the dollar amount that she paid. Be sure to specify what the variables represent.

Compare your answer to the sample response:
\( 6a + 9𝑓 = 75 \)


4. Here is a graph that represents the quantities in this situation.



a. Choose any point on the line, state its coordinates, and explain what it tells us.
b. Choose any point that is not on the line, state its coordinates, and explain what it tells us.

Compare your answers to the sample responses:
a. Point A or \((2, 7)\): Clare bought 2 pounds of almonds and 7 pounds of figs for a total of $75.
b. Point D or \((1, 1)\): Clare bought 1 pound of almonds and 1 pound of figs, and the total was not $75.




Video: Using a Graph to Solve an Equation

Watch the following video to further explore the above scenario.

page.title: 1.5.2: Self Check
page.contents: Which point is a solution to the line graphed below?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: When \( x=3 \), \( y=1 \), so this point is a solution on the graph.

Incorrect. This point is located above the line that is graphed. Let’s try again a different way: When a point is a solution to an equation, it must be located on the graph of the equation. The answer is \( (3, 1) \)

Incorrect. To get to \( (1, 3) \), you move 1 right from the origin and 3 up, so this point is not on the line. Let’s try again a different way: When a point is a solution to an equation, it must be located on the graph of the equation. The answer is \( (3, 1) \).

Incorrect. To get to \( (−3, 3) \), move 3 left and then 3 up. This point is not a solution to the equation of the line graphed. Let’s try again a different way: When a point is a solution to an equation, it must be located on the graph of the equation. The answer is \( (3, 1) \).

page.title: 1.5.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Determining the Meaning of Solutions of a Graphed Line

Suppose we are buying beans and rice to feed a large gathering of people, and we plan to spend $120 on the two ingredients. Beans cost $2 a pound, and rice costs $0.50 a pound.

If \( x \) represents pounds of beans and \( y \) pounds of rice, the equation \( 2x + 0.50y = 120 \) can represent the constraints in this situation.

The graph of \( 2x + 0.50y = 120 \) shows a straight line.



Each point on the line is a pair of \( x \)- and \( y \)-values that make the equation true and is thus a solution. It is also a pair of values that satisfy the constraints in the situation.

  • The point \( (10, 200) \) is on the line. If we buy 10 pounds of beans and 200 pounds of rice, the cost will be \( 2(10) + 0.50(200) \), which equals 120.
  • The points \( (60, 0) \) and \( (45, 60) \) are also on the line. If we buy only beans—60 pounds of them—and no rice, we will spend $120. If we buy 45 pounds of beans and 60 pounds of rice, we will also spend $120.

What about points that are not on the line? They are not solutions because they don’t satisfy the constraints, but they still have meaning in the situation.

  • The point \( (20, 80) \) is not on the line. Buying 20 pounds of beans and 80 pounds of rice costs \( 2(20) + 0.50(80) \) or 80, which does not equal 120. This combination costs less than what we intend to spend.
  • The point \( (70, 180) \) means that we buy 70 pounds of beans and 180 pounds of rice. It will cost \( 2(70)+0.50(180) \) or 230, which is over our budget of 120.

Let’s look at an example.

Looking again at the graph above, would the point \((30, 120)\) be a solution, and what is the meaning in the situation?

Yes; the point means that 30 pounds of beans and 120 pounds of rice were purchased. Since the point is on the line, the total spent was $120.

Try It: Determining the Meaning of Solutions of a Graphed Line

At a high school baseball game, the concession stand sold hot dogs and hamburgers. Hot dogs were $1.50, and hamburgers cost $3. The goal is to make $150 for the game.

What is the meaning of the point \((40, 30)\) on the graph?


Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine the meaning of the point \( (40, 30) \) on this graph. The \( x \)-axis is labeled “number of hot dogs,” and the \( y \)-axis is labeled “number of hamburgers.” Since \( x = 40\), there were 40 hot dogs sold, and since \( y = 30\), there were 30 hamburgers sold. Since the point is on the line, the total amount from the hot dogs and hamburgers sold was $150.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I'd like to retry the self check.
I'm ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.5.3: Writing, Graphing, and Solving a Linear Equation
page.contents:
Activity

1. A student has a savings account with $475 in it. She deposits $125 of her paycheck into the account every week. Her goal is to save $7,000 for college.

a. How much will be in the account after 3 weeks?
b. How long will it take until she has $1,350?
c. Write an equation that represents the relationship between the dollar amount in her account and the number of weeks of saving.
d. Graph your equation using graphing technology. Mark the points on the graph that represent the amount after 3 weeks and the week she has $1,350. Write down the coordinates.
e. How long will it take her to reach her goal?

Check and compare your answers:
a. $850
b. 7 weeks
c. Sample response: \( 𝑎 = 475 + 125𝑤 \), where \( a \) is the dollar amount in the account and \( w \) is the number of weeks of savings
d. 

e. 53 weeks


2. A 450-gallon tank full of water is draining at a rate of 20 gallons per minute.

a. How many gallons will be in the tank after 7 minutes?
b. How long will it take for the tank to have 200 gallons?
c. Write an equation that represents the relationship between the gallons of water in the tank and minutes the tank has been draining.
d. Graph your equation using graphing technology. Mark the points on the graph that represent the gallons after 7 minutes and the time when the tank has 200 gallons. Write down the coordinates.
e. How long will it take until the tank is empty?

Check and compare your answers:
a. 310 gallons
b. 12.5 minutes, or 12 minutes 30 seconds
c. Sample equation: \( 𝑎 = 450 − 20𝑡 \), where \( a \) is the amount in the tank and \( t \) is time in minutes
d. 

e. 22.5 minutes, or 22 minutes 30 seconds

 

Extending Your Thinking

1. Write an equation that represents the relationship between the gallons of water in the tank and hours the tank has been draining.

Enter your answer here:

Check and compare your answer: \( a = 450 − 1,200h \) where \( h \) is time in hours


2. Write an equation that represents the relationship between the gallons of water in the tank and seconds the tank has been draining.
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:
\( a = 450 - \frac{s}{3} \) where \( s \) is time in seconds



3. Graph each of your new equations. In what way are all of the graphs the same? In what way are they all different? Write down your answer. Select the Solution button when you are ready to check your work.





4. How would these graphs change if we used quarts of water instead of gallons? What would stay the same?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:
The graphs would still be lines with negative slopes that are different. They would have the same horizontal intercepts. The vertical intercepts would be different, but they would represent the same amount of water.

page.title: 1.5.4: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 2
page.contents:
Cool-Down Activity

A ceramic sugar bowl weighs 340 grams when empty. It is then filled with sugar. One tablespoon of sugar weighs 12.5 grams.

1. Write an equation to represent the relationship between the total weight of the bowl in grams, \( W \), and the tablespoons of sugar, \( T \).
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:
\( W = 340 + 12.5T \), or \( 340 + 12.5T = W \)


2. When the sugar bowl is full, it weighs 740 grams. How many tablespoons of sugar can the bowl hold? Show your reasoning.
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer to the sample response:
32 tablespoons;
\( 740 = 340 + 12.5T \)
\( 400 = 12.5T \); Subtract 340 from both sides.
\( 32 = T \); Divide both sides by 12.5.


3. The graph represents the relationship between the number of tablespoons of sugar in the bowl and the total weight of the bowl. 

Which point on the graph could represent your answer to the previous question?
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:
Point \( D \), because its coordinates could be \( (32, 740) \).


4. About how many tablespoons of sugar are in the bowl when the total weight is 600 grams?
Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:
About 21 tablespoons

page.title: 1.5.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Equations Using Graphs in Situations 

An equation that contains two unknown quantities or two quantities that vary is called an equation in two variables. A solution to such an equation is a pair of numbers that makes the equation true. 

Suppose Tyler spends $45 on T-shirts and socks. A T-shirt costs $10, and a pair of socks costs $2.50. If \( t \) represents the number of T-shirts and \( p \) represents the number of pairs of socks that Tyler buys, what is an equation that represents the situation?

The cost is $10 per T-shirt \( (10t) \) plus $2.50 per pair of socks \( (2.50p) \), which equals $45. 

\( 10t +2.50p = 45 \)

Let’s look at the graph of this equation: 

What does the point \( (2, 10) \) mean in this graph in relation to the situation?

Tyler bought 2 T-shirts and 10 pairs of socks for $45.

What does the point \( (4, 6) \) mean on this graph? 

If Tyler bought 4 T-shirts and 6 pairs of socks, it would cost MORE than $45.

Try It: Writing Equations Using Graphs in Situations 

Use Desmos or a graphing calculator to create a graph for \( 40x +20y = 180 \). 

If \(x\) represents the number of pairs of shoes and \(y\) represents the number of pairs of jeans, what is one combination that is a solution, and what does it mean on the graph?

Write down your answer, and then select the Solution button to check your work.


Sample answer: \( (2, 5) \)
Buying 2 pairs of shoes and 5 pairs of jeans will cost $180. 

Here is how to find a solution and its meaning: 

Find a point on the graph. The point \( (2, 5) \) is on the graph. Since 2 is the \( x \)-coordinate, it represents 2 pairs of shoes. Since 5 is the \( y \)-coordinate, it represents 5 pairs of jeans. The line represents all combinations that equal $180.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 1.5.3: Self Check
page.contents: Which of the following points is a solution to the graph below?

answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: When \( x=2, y=3(2)+1=7 \).
Incorrect. When \(x =0\) and \(y= 3\), the point is not on the line so it is not a solution. Let’s try again a different way: Find a point that is on the line. The correct answer is \( (2, 7) \).
Incorrect. Make sure to always write the \(x\)-coordinate first in the ordered pair. Let’s try again a different way: Find a point that is on the line. The correct answer is \( (2, 7) \).
Incorrect. When \(x = -2\) and \(y =-6\), the point is not on the line so it is not a solution. Let’s try again a different way: Find a point that is on the line. The correct answer is \( (2, 7) \).

page.title: 1.5.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

The graph of \( y=-x+4 \) is shown.


For questions 1–4, for each ordered pair, decide:

  • Is the ordered pair a solution to the equation?
  • Is the point on the line?

1.

  a. Is the ordered pair (0,4) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  b. Is the point (0,4) on the line?

 

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

2.

    a. Is the ordered pair (-1,3) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    b. Is the point (-1,3) on the line?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is No. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

3.

   a. Is the ordered pair (2,2) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

   b. Is the point (2,2) on the line?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

4.

   a. Is the ordered pair (-2,6) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5-6, use the graph of y = 3x − 1 as shown.

[Insert Graph]


For questions 5-6, for each ordered pair, decide:

  • Is the ordered pair a solution to the equation?
  • Is the point on the line?

   b. Is the point (-2,6) on the line?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

For questions 5-6, use the graph of y = 3x − 1 as shown.

[Insert Graph]


For questions 5-6, for each ordered pair, decide:

  • Is the ordered pair a solution to the equation?
  • Is the point on the line?

5.

   a. Is the ordered pair (0,-1) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

   b. Is the point (0,-1) on the line?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

6.

   a. Is the ordered pair (2,5) a solution to the equation?

Correct!

Try again. Why don't you go back to activity 1.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

   b. Is the point (2,5) on the line?

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

7. Select all the points that are on the graph of the equation 4y − 6x = 12.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 1.5.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is A, B, D. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

8. Here is a graph of the equation \(x+3y=6\).

Select all coordinate pairs that represent a solution to the equation.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 1.5.2 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is A, D. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 1.5.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use graphing technology to graph linear equations and identify solutions to the equations.
  • Explain how the coordinates of the points on the graph of a linear equation are related to the equation.
  • Explain the meaning of points on a graph in terms of the situation it represents when given the graph of a linear equation.
Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 1.5.1: Analyzing Graphs of Linear Equations 
    • In this activity, you compared the characteristics of similar, yet different, graphs. In graphs, slopes, intercepts, axis labels, and where points are located can all create different meanings.
  • 1.5.2: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 1
    • In this activity, you determined if a point was on the graph of a linear equation and what the meaning of that point was in a given situation.
  • 1.5.2: Self Check 
  • 1.5.3: Writing, Graphing, and Solving a Linear Equation
    • In this activity, you wrote equations, graphed the equations, and used the graph to help solve the equations and find the meaning of solutions.
  • 1.5.3: Self Check 
  • 1.5.4: Examining an Equation in Two Variables and Its Graph, Part 2
    • In this activity, you wrote equations to express relationships. You also looked at graphs and determined the meaning of points on the graph to answer questions. 

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 1.5.5: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
